body:
Tested on: qTox 1.15.0, 1.16.0, 1.16.1; FreeBSD 11.1 and 11.2, amd64 and i386.
After upgrade toxcore-0.2.2_2,1 to toxcore-0.2.3,1 qTox began to exit self without errors or coredumps.
Sometimes in few seconds, sometimes after 10-20 hours. With IPv6 on in config qTox exit faster.

Build toxcore and qTox with -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug and run with gdb:
```
$ gdb qtox

GDB is free software, covered by the GNU General Public License, and you are
welcome to change it and/or distribute copies of it under certain conditions.
Type "show copying" to see the conditions.
There is absolutely no warranty for GDB.  Type "show warranty" for details.
This GDB was configured as "amd64-marcel-freebsd"...(no debugging symbols found)...
(gdb) run

[12:52:42.968 UTC] :0 : Warning: QStandardPaths: XDG_RUNTIME_DIR not set, defaulting to '/tmp/runtime-vvd'
[12:52:44.174 UTC] persistence/settings.cpp:133 : Debug: "Loading settings from /home/vvd/.config/tox/qtox.ini"
[12:52:44.312 UTC] widget/translator.cpp:51 : Debug: Loaded translation "ru"

[12:52:44.401 UTC] main.cpp:227 : Debug: Log file over 1MB, rotating...
[12:52:44.402 UTC] main.cpp:237 : Debug: Removed old log successfully
[12:52:44.405 UTC] main.cpp:258 : Debug: commit:  build without git
[12:52:44.501 UTC] persistence/profile.cpp:117 : Debug: Loading tox save  "/home/vvd/.config/tox/VVD.tox"
[12:52:44.509 UTC] persistence/settings.cpp:462 : Debug: "Saving global settings at /home/vvd/.config/tox/qtox.ini"
[12:52:44.532 UTC] persistence/settings.cpp:335 : Debug: Loading personal settings from "/home/vvd/.config/tox/VVD.ini"
[12:52:44.545 UTC] nexus.cpp:87 : Debug: Starting up

[12:52:47.973 UTC] core/core.cpp:202 : Debug: Loading user profile
[12:52:47.973 UTC] core/toxoptions.cpp:65 : Warning: Core starting with IPv6 disabled. LAN discovery may not work properly.
[12:52:56.372 UTC] persistence/profile.cpp:82 : Debug: Self avatar not found, will broadcast empty avatar to friends
[12:52:56.689 UTC] widget/systemtrayicon.cpp:83 : Debug: Using the Qt backend
[12:52:57.861 UTC] core/core.cpp:357 : Debug: "Connecting to toxnode.nek0.net:33445 (Phsm)"
[12:52:58.107 UTC] core/toxlogger.cpp:56 : Warning: "ERROR:network.c:sendpacket:562: attempted to send message with network family 10 (probably IPv6) on IPv4 socket"
[12:52:58.123 UTC] core/core.cpp:357 : Debug: "Connecting to 2a01:d0:ffff:a8a::2:33445 (strngr)"

[12:53:01.261 UTC] core/toxlogger.cpp:56 : Warning: "ERROR:network.c:sendpacket:562: attempted to send message with network family 10 (probably IPv6) on IPv4 socket"
[12:53:02.260 UTC] core/toxlogger.cpp:56 : Warning: "ERROR:network.c:sendpacket:562: attempted to send message with network family 10 (probably IPv6) on IPv4 socket"
[12:53:02.760 UTC] core/core.cpp:357 : Debug: "Connecting to 95.215.44.78:33445 (HooinKyoma)"
[12:53:02.760 UTC] core/core.cpp:357 : Debug: "Connecting to 205.185.116.116:33445 (Busindre)"

Program received signal SIGPIPE, Broken pipe.

        m = (Messenger *) 0x83b81b800

        tolerance = 90

No locals.

    which=1, this_=0x833dcdec0, r=0x833c4ba40, a=0x7fffdf3f7960, ret=0x0) at qobjectdefs_impl.h:398
No locals.
```

comment_data.body:
I'm confused.

https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/ae7899cab8104fa3c3078a3e61ddfa58a826e39a/toxcore/network.c#L1588

sets `MSG_NOSIGNAL` telling FreeBSD not to send a signal, yet FreBSD sends us a signal:

>Program received signal SIGPIPE, Broken pipe.

It's even documented in FreeBSD manpage:

>[#define MSG_NOSIGNAL    0x20000 /*	do not generate	SIGPIPE	on EOF */](https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=send&sektion=2)

which matches the Linux's behaviour:

>[       MSG_NOSIGNAL (since Linux 2.2)
              Don't generate a SIGPIPE signal if the peer on a stream-
              oriented socket has closed the connection.  The EPIPE error is
              still returned.  This provides similar behavior to using
              sigaction(2) to ignore SIGPIPE, but, whereas MSG_NOSIGNAL is a
              per-call feature, ignoring SIGPIPE sets a process attribute
              that affects all threads in the process.](http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/sendmsg.2.html)

yet Linux doesn't send a signal but FreeBSD does. What is going on here?
Just to point out, [some of our tests fail on FreeBSD Travis](https://travis-ci.org/TokTok/c-toxcore/jobs/403938871#L1901) due to what seems to be the same issue:  "***Exception: SIGPIPE".

For linux 2.2+:
```send(sockfd, buf, sizeof(buf), MSG_NOSIGNAL );```
For BSD:
```
int set = 1;
setsockopt(sd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_NOSIGPIPE, (void *)&set, sizeof(int));
```
Universal, but more global:
```signal(SIGPIPE, SIG_IGN);```
Â© https://stackoverflow.com/questions/108183/how-to-prevent-sigpipes-or-handle-them-properly

BTW, it work with 0.2.2 - what was changed in 0.2.3?

But FreeBSD manpages say that `MSG_NOSIGNAL` works too. Is it lying?

>BTW, it work with 0.2.2 - what was changed in 0.2.3?

No idea, @iphydf might know, I haven't been following PRs lately.

> But FreeBSD manpages say that ```MSG_NOSIGNAL``` works too. Is it lying?

Don't know. Never used it. Always ```signal(SIGPIPE, SIG_IGN);```.

The thing is that `signal(SIGPIPE, SIG_IGN);` would ignore it on per-process basis, e.g. if a Tox client relies on receiving `SIGPIPE` signals it won't be receiving them anymore because toxcore disabled it.

This patch fixed the issue:
```
--- network.c.orig
+++ network.c
@@ -30,7 +30,7 @@
 #endif
 
 #ifndef _XOPEN_SOURCE
-#define _XOPEN_SOURCE 600
+#define _XOPEN_SOURCE 700
 #endif
 
 #if defined(_WIN32) && _WIN32_WINNT >= _WIN32_WINNT_WINXP
```

It might work as a quickfix, but we need to find out what exactly caused it to break in the first place. You said that it worked in v0.2.2, that's what v0.2.2 does

https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/2824daf74a6d2bd60ebaf387a30f1b7719b6b67c/toxcore/network.c#L32-L34

and it was working fine, so `_XOPEN_SOURCE` not being set to 700 is not an issue, it was working fine with 600, something else caused it. There might be a bigger issue that we are missing.
@VVD is this issue fixed now in master?
It work fine now. And 0.2.2 work fine.

Don't agree with this issue being closed. We still haven't found the actual root problem that has caused the issue, we have only found a way to alleviate the effects of whatever the bug in toxcore is, the bug itself is still somewhere there.

title: qTox: "Program received signal SIGPIPE, Broken pipe." with TokTok-c-toxcore-v0.2.3_GH0 on FreeBSD 11.x.
